questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a painful thyroid gland and hyperthyroidism. Laboratory findings show elevated ESR, and imaging reveals diffusely enlarged thyroid tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Hashimoto's thyroiditis): Incorrect. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is a painless condition that initially causes hyperthyroidism but progresses to prolonged hypothyroidism. It is not associated with elevated ESR or pain.

Option B (Subacute/De Quervain thyroiditis): Correct. Subacute thyroiditis presents with a painful thyroid gland, initial hyperthyroidism, and elevated ESR. It is self-limiting and may progress to hypothyroidism before resolving spontaneously.

Option C (Riedel's thyroiditis): Incorrect. Riedel's thyroiditis presents with a painless, hard thyroid gland and is not associated with hyperthyroidism or elevated ESR.

Option D (Grave's disease): Incorrect. Grave's disease is painless and associated with hyperthyroidism due to autoimmune stimulation of TSH receptors but does not involve a painful thyroid gland or elevated ESR.

Tags:

Topic: Inflammatory Thyroiditis

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-55, page no. 872.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with sensorineural hearing loss and a goiter. Genetic testing reveals an abnormality on chromosome 7q. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Wolff-Chaikoff effect): Incorrect. The Wolff-Chaikoff effect refers to iodine-induced hypothyroidism due to temporary suppression of thyroid hormone synthesis. It is unrelated to hearing loss or chromosome 7q abnormalities.

Option B (Jod Basedow effect): Incorrect. The Jod Basedow effect describes iodine-induced hyperthyroidism, not associated with hearing loss or chromosomal defects.

Option C (Pendred syndrome): Correct. Pendred syndrome is characterized by congenital sensory neural hearing loss and goiter. The genetic mutation associated with this condition is located on chromosome 7q.

Option D (Refetoff syndrome): Incorrect. Refetoff syndrome involves end-organ resistance to T4, presenting as hypothyroidism but not associated with hearing loss or chromosome 7q mutations.

Tags:

Topic: Thyroid Disorders

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-55, page no. 852.

choices.text: Benign thyroid nodule; TSH suppression therapy

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a thyroid nodule. Ultrasound shows a hypoechoic nodule with microcalcifications and a taller-than-wide orientation. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Option A (Benign thyroid nodule; observation): Incorrect. Hypoechoic nodules with microcalcifications and taller-than-wide orientation are suggestive of malignancy, not benignity.

Option B (Malignant thyroid nodule; FNAC): Correct. These features indicate a high suspicion for malignancy, warranting further evaluation with fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) to confirm the diagnosis.

Option C (Benign thyroid nodule; TSH suppression therapy): Incorrect. TSH suppression is used in select benign conditions, not in nodules with malignant features.

Option D (Malignant thyroid nodule; thyroidectomy): Incorrect. While thyroidectomy may be needed later, FNAC is required first to confirm malignancy.

Benign vs Malignant Characteristics

  • Benign:
    • Isoechoic
    • Macro-calcifications
    • Wider > taller
  • Malignant:
    • Hypoechoic
    • Micro-calcifications
    • Taller > wider
  • Other Features:
    • Peripheral vascular vascularity
  • TIRADS Score : Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System
  • Criteria:
    • Composition
    • Margin
    • Shape
    • Echogenicity
    • Echogenic foci

Next Step: FNAC is essential to confirm the diagnosis before planning definitive treatment.

Tags:

Topic: Thyroid Nodules

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 55, page no. -853.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. FNAC reveals thyroid tissue. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Option A (Total thyroidectomy): Incorrect. Total thyroidectomy is not indicated unless there is a separate thyroid malignancy or no other functional thyroid tissue.

Option B (Excision of the swelling only): Incorrect. Simple excision leads to recurrence because it does not address the thyroglossal tract.

Option C (Sistrunk procedure): Correct. The Sistrunk procedure involves excision of the cyst, part of the hyoid bone, and the entire thyroglossal tract up to the base of the tongue, which is the standard treatment.

Option D (Thyroid hormone suppression therapy): Incorrect. Hormonal therapy is not curative and is only indicated if the lingual thyroid is the only functional thyroid tissue.

Key Points:

Thyroglossal Cyst:

  • Etiology: Persistent thyroglossal duct.
  • Site: Midline neck swelling; moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion.
  • Diagnosis: FNAC and imaging to confirm normal thyroid tissue before surgery.
  • Sistrunk Procedure:Includes removal of the cyst, part of the hyoid bone, and the entire thyroglossal tract to prevent recurrence.

Tags:

Topic: Thyroglossal Cyst Management

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 55, page no. 852.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common thyroid carcinoma and its associated genetic mutation?
questions.solution:
Option A (Follicular carcinoma; K-RAS): Incorrect. While follicular carcinoma is associated with the K-RAS mutation and hematogenous metastasis, it is not the most common thyroid carcinoma.

Option B (Medullary carcinoma; RET): Incorrect. Medullary carcinoma originates from parafollicular cells and is associated with RET mutations, especially in MEN II syndrome, but it is not the most common type.

Option C (Papillary carcinoma; BRAF): Correct. Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma, accounting for the majority of cases. It is associated with BRAF and RET-PTC mutations, and metastasis occurs via lymphatics.

Option D (Anaplastic carcinoma; P53): Incorrect. Anaplastic carcinoma has the worst prognosis and is associated with P53 mutations, but it is the least common type of thyroid carcinoma.

Tags:

Topic: Thyroid Malignancies

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 55, page no. -868.

choices.text: Lingual thyroid is treated by the Sistrunk procedure
Thyroglossal cyst requires thyroid hormone supplementation
Lingual thyroid must be evaluated for normal thyroid tissue before excision
Thyroglossal cyst is managed by excision without removal of the hyoid bone

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of lingual thyroid and thyroglossal cyst?
questions.solution:
Option A (Lingual thyroid is treated by the Sistrunk procedure): Incorrect. Lingual thyroid is managed with excision if symptomatic, and thyroid hormone supplementation is required if it is the only functioning thyroid tissue. The Sistrunk procedure is specific for thyroglossal cyst.

Option B (Thyroglossal cyst requires thyroid hormone supplementation): Incorrect. Thyroglossal cyst does not typically require thyroid hormone supplementation unless there is associated hypothyroidism.

Option C (Lingual thyroid must be evaluated for normal thyroid tissue before excision): Correct. Evaluation with ultrasound or scintigraphy is essential to ensure there is functioning thyroid tissue elsewhere before removing a lingual thyroid, as it might be the only source of thyroid hormone.

Option D (Thyroglossal cyst is managed by excision without removal of the hyoid bone): Incorrect. The Sistrunk procedure involves removal of the cyst, part of the hyoid bone, and the tract to the base of the tongue to prevent recurrence.

Tags:

Topic: Lingual Thyroid, Thyroglossal Cyst

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 55, page number -868.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in the Van-Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)?
questions.solution:
Option A (Microcalcification): Correct. Microcalcification is an important component of VNPI and is used to assess the extent and aggressiveness of DCIS.

Option B (Size of the tumor): Correct. Tumor size is a key factor in VNPI and directly impacts treatment decisions.

Option C (Lymph node involvement): Incorrect. VNPI does not consider lymph node involvement because DCIS is a non-invasive lesion and does not metastasize to lymph nodes.

Option D (Grade of the tumor): Correct. Tumor grade is a critical factor in VNPI as it reflects the biological aggressiveness of DCIS.

  • Van-Nuys prognostic index (VNPI)
    • It is for DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma in Situ) .
    • Low-grade DCIS treatment is sufficient. Lumpectomy is done.
    • High-grade DCIS, apart from lumpectomy .Radiotherapy is also given.
    • VNPIis based on (Micro SWAG)
    • Micro calcification
    • Size Of Tumor
    • Width of margin
    • Age Of Patient
    • Grade of tumor

Tags:

Topic: DCIS, VNPI

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-58, page number:932

choices.text: Aromatase inhibitors are preferred in pre-menopausal women
Tamoxifen increases the risk of osteoporosis in post-menopausal women
Aromatase inhibitors are associated with a higher risk of endometrial hyperplasia
Tamoxifen is the standard hormonal therapy for pre-menopausal women

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding hormonal therapy for breast cancer in pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women?
questions.solution:
Option A (Aromatase inhibitors are preferred in pre-menopausal women): Incorrect. Aromatase inhibitors are the preferred therapy for post-menopausal women, as they reduce estrogen production by blocking the aromatase enzyme, which is active in post-menopausal women.

Option B (Tamoxifen increases the risk of osteoporosis in post-menopausal women): Incorrect. Tamoxifen actually has a protective effect against osteoporosis by acting as an estrogen agonist on bone in post-menopausal women.

Option C (Aromatase inhibitors are associated with a higher risk of endometrial hyperplasia): Incorrect. Aromatase inhibitors are not associated with endometrial hyperplasia; this side effect is linked to Tamoxifen, which acts as an estrogen agonist in the uterus.

Option D (Tamoxifen is the standard hormonal therapy for pre-menopausal women): Correct. Tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), is the standard hormonal therapy for pre-menopausal women with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

Tags:

Topic: Breast Cancer, Hormonal Therapy

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 58, page number. -941.

choices.text: Large tumor in a small breast

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to Breast-Conserving Surgery (BCS)?
questions.solution:
Option A (Large tumor in a small breast): Incorrect. This is a relative contraindication. While conserving the breast may be challenging, it is not strictly prohibited.

Option B (Pregnancy): Correct. Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication to BCS due to the potential harm of radiotherapy, which is essential after BCS, to the developing fetus.

Option C (Centrally located tumor): Incorrect. Centrally located tumors are a relative contraindication because nipple reconstruction is technically challenging but not impossible.

Option D (Large pendulous breast): Incorrect. This is a relative contraindication due to challenges in administering uniform radiotherapy, but it is not an absolute contraindication.

Contraindications to BCS

Tags:

Topic: Breast-Conserving Surgery

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 58, page number. -935.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a rapidly enlarging breast mass associated with redness, edema, and Peau d'orange appearance. Clinical examination reveals diffuse skin changes over the entire breast without any palpable ulceration or satellite nodules. What is the most likely TNM classification for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A (T4a): Incorrect. T4a refers to extension to the chest wall, including the ribs, intercostal muscles, and serratus anterior, but without skin involvement.

Option B (T4b): Incorrect. T4b includes localized skin involvement such as ulceration, edema (peau d'orange), or satellite nodules, all confined to the same breast, but does not describe inflammatory breast cancer.

Option C (T4c): Incorrect. T4c combines features of T4a (chest wall invasion) and T4b (localized skin changes), but the diffuse inflammatory changes seen here are not limited to these categories.

Option D (T4d): Correct. T4d represents inflammatory breast cancer, characterized by rapid onset of diffuse redness, edema, and Peau d'orange appearance without ulceration or a palpable satellite nodule.

Key Points:

  1. T4a: Chest wall involvement (ribs, intercostal muscles, serratus anterior).
  2. T4b: Skin involvement (ulceration, peau d'orange, satellite nodules).
  3. T4c: Combination of T4a and T4b.
  4. T4d: Inflammatory breast cancer (diffuse erythema and edema involving the entire breast).

Tags:

Topic: Breast Cancer Staging, TNM Classification

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 58, page no. -933.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with unilateral itching and erythema over the nipple-areolar complex. On examination, the nipple shows destruction, and a palpable lump is identified in the underlying breast tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Paget's Disease): Correct. Paget's disease is characterized by unilateral nipple-areolar changes, itching, destruction of the nipple, and an associated underlying breast lump (commonly invasive ductal carcinoma or DCIS).

Option B (Eczema): Incorrect. Eczema affects the nipple bilaterally, is associated with itching, but does not involve nipple destruction or an underlying breast lump.

Option C (Breast Abscess): Incorrect. A breast abscess presents with localized redness, tenderness, and swelling, often associated with infection and pus formation, not nipple destruction or an underlying lump.

Option D (Inflammatory Breast Cancer): Incorrect. Inflammatory breast cancer presents with rapid-onset breast swelling, erythema, and Peau d'orange appearance, not nipple destruction or eczema-like changes.

Tags:

Topic: Paget's Disease

Difficulty Level: Moderate

PYQ: NEET SS

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter - 58, page no. -924.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a unilateral bloody nipple discharge from a single duct. She has no associated pain or visible lumps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Duct ectasia): Incorrect. Duct ectasia is more commonly associated with green or bluish nipple discharge and involves multiple ducts.

Option B (Duct papilloma): Correct. A duct papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge from a single duct without other alarming signs.

Option C (Prolactinoma): Incorrect. Prolactinoma typically presents with milkish discharge (galactorrhea), not bloody discharge.

Option D (Breast cancer): Incorrect. While breast cancer can cause bloody discharge, it is often associated with other clinical findings such as a palpable lump or skin changes.

Tags:

Topic: Nipple Discharge

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter-58, page no. -925.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) undergoes neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Imaging after treatment reveals the disappearance of all lesions and pathological lymph nodes. What is the correct response classification?
questions.solution:
Option A (Partial Response): Incorrect. PR is defined as a ≥30% reduction in the single largest diameter (SLD) without new lesions or progression of non-target lesions, but the lesions do not completely disappear.

Option B (Stable Disease): Incorrect. SD refers to no significant reduction (≥30%) or increase (≥20%) in SLD, and no progression or new lesions.

Option C (Pathological Complete Response): Correct. TNBC is associated with high pCR rates. The disappearance of all lesions and pathological lymph nodes after treatment confirms pCR.

Option D (Progressive Disease): Incorrect. PD involves a ≥20% increase in SLD, progression of non-target lesions, or appearance of new lesions, which is not seen in this case.

Key Points:

  • Complete Response (CR): Disappearance of all lesions and pathological lymph node
  • Pathological Complete Response (pCR): Highest rates seen in TNBC patients; indicates no residual invasive cancer in the breast or lymph nodes.
  • Partial Response (PR): ≥30% reduction in SLD
  • Stable Disease (SD): No significant change in lesion size (≥30% reduction or ≥20% increase).
  • Progressive Disease (PD): ≥20% increase in SLD, progression, or new lesions.

Tags:

Topic: Response Evaluation Criteria

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 58, page number -935.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female is diagnosed with breast cancer. Her tumor is estrogen receptor-positive, progesterone receptor-positive, HER2/neu-negative, and has low Ki-67 levels. What is the most likely molecular subtype of her breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option A (Luminal A): Correct. Luminal A breast cancer is characterized by positive hormone receptor status (ER and/or PR), HER2/neu negativity, and low Ki-67 levels, indicating a less aggressive tumor.

Option B (Luminal B): Incorrect. Although Luminal B also has positive hormone receptor status, it is differentiated by high Ki-67 levels, indicating a more proliferative and aggressive tumor.

Option C (HER2/neu enriched): Incorrect. This subtype is HER2/neu-positive and hormone receptor-negative, which does not match the described tumor profile.

Option D (Basal type): Incorrect. Basal-type tumors (triple-negative) are negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu, and often have high Ki-67 levels, which does not align with the patient's tumor characteristics.

Tags:

Topic: Breast Cancer Molecular Subtypes

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter -58, page no. 931

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a palpable breast nodule. Biopsy reveals apocrine cysts, and sclerosing adenosis, multiple papillomas with atypia. Family history is positive for breast cancer. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is her relative risk (RR) for developing breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Option A (Solitary papilloma; RR 1.5-2): Incorrect. Solitary papilloma is characterized by a single papilloma within a duct, associated with a relative risk of 1.5-2 for breast cancer. This presentation involves multiple papillomas and additional features like apocrine cysts and sclerosing adenosis, ruling out solitary papilloma.

Option B (Papillomatosis; RR 3): Incorrect. Papillomatosis involves five or more papillomas in multiple ducts, often bilaterally. Although the RR matches, this case specifically describes features consistent with juvenile papillomatosis.

Option C (Juvenile papillomatosis; RR 3): Correct. Juvenile papillomatosis, also known as Swiss cheese disease, is characterized by multiple papillomas with atypia, apocrine cysts, ductal hyperplasia, and sclerosing adenosis. It typically affects younger women and is associated with an RR of 3 for breast cancer.

Option D (Atypical ductal hyperplasia; RR 4-5): Incorrect. ADH is defined as ductal hyperplasia with atypia and a relative risk of 4-5 for breast cancer. It is not characterized by the presence of multiple papillomas and associated findings described in this case.

Key Points:

  • Solitary Papilloma: RR 1.5-2 for cancer.
  • Papillomatosis: Five or more papillomas in multiple ducts; RR 3.
  • Juvenile Papillomatosis: Multiple papillomas with atypia, apocrine cysts, and sclerosing adenosis; RR 3.
  • Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia with atypia involving more than two ducts; RR 4-5.

Tags:

Topic: Breast Pathology, Risk Stratification

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, Chapter- 58, page no. 919.
